caption: This is a bronze of a Greek theatre actor that you will find in the northeast corner of the Luxembourg Gardens near the Medici Fountain. It is the work of Charles-Arthur Bourgeois (1868) and is a classical pose of a performer in sheepskin wrapped around his waist and mask raised above his forehead as he reads from a manuscript.  Behind the Greek Actor sculpture you will see the Pantheon, making for a good backdrop for photos.

The bronze statue of an ancient Greek actor is one of more than 100 sculptures and monuments spread across the Luxembourg Gardens.
A bronze statue of the Greek actor made by the sculptor Charles-Arthur Bourgeois can be discovered in the Luxembourg Gardens and gives a view of the Pantheon.

Explicit and direct homage to the culture of ancient Greece and to the strength of its theatre, with this sculpture which sends the visitor back to times and places far from this garden, but whose canons of beauty and art have been inherited, while the perspective he runs along the tree-lined avenue and flees towards the Parthenon, located at the top of the avenue outside the park a little further on. The statue represents an actor with a sheepskin and a mask raised on his head reading from a manuscript. It is made of cast bronze and is 2.10 meters high; dates back to 1868.

The sculpture of the Greek Actor was created for the 1868 salon by Baron Charles-Arthur Bourgeois [1838-1886]. The bronze represents the actor, a mask raised on his forehead, rehearsing his role by reciting his text written on parchment. Then presented at the Universal Exhibition of 1878 where it obtained a third class medal then erected at the Od√©on theater to finish today in the Luxembourg Gardens in Paris.
